questionText: Which symbol is used when declaring a pointer?
What does the & operator do in C?
options: Gets the value at the address stored in a pointer
Returns the size of a variable
Declares a new variable
Gets the memory address of a variable

questionText: What happens when you try to dereference a null pointer (NULL)?
options: Undefined behavior will occur (e.g., a segmentation fault)
The program will terminate correctly
The value 0 will be returned
The pointer will automatically get a new address

questionText: What does the value NULL mean for a pointer?
options: The pointer points to a memory location containing the value 0
The pointer is uninitialized and contains a garbage value
The pointer explicitly does not point to any valid memory address
The pointer points to the last byte of memory

questionText: Which of the following statements about pointers are true? (Choose all that apply)
options: A pointer must be of the same data type as the object it points to
Dereferencing an uninitialized pointer leads to undefined behavior
The C language supports references in the same way as C++
You should always check if a pointer is not NULL before dereferencing it
correctAnswers: A pointer must be of the same data type as the object it points to
Dereferencing an uninitialized pointer leads to undefined behavior
You should always check if a pointer is not NULL before dereferencing it

questionText: How does the & (address-of) operator differ from the * (dereference) operator?
options: Both operators perform the same function
& returns the address of a variable, while * returns the value at the address stored in a pointer
* returns the address of a variable, while & returns the value at that address
& is used for arithmetic operations, while * is used for logical operations
The address of variable x
A random garbage value

questionText: Why is initializing pointers considered an important safety practice?
options: It speeds up program execution.
Uninitialized pointers occupy less memory.
It prevents undefined behavior from accidental dereferencing.
The compiler requires mandatory initialization of all variables.
